Award.AwardTitle: Two-Stage Buffer Layers for Solar Power in a InGaP - Si Double Junction Cell

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Intellectual Merit
The objective of this project is to monolithically integrate In0.50Ga0.50P on Si wafer substrates by using a thin nucleation layer of Ge followed by a metamorphic buffer comprised of step-graded InxGa1-xP. The thin 3 ML Ge layer will provide a nucleation template for the step-graded InxGa1-xP as well as provide a coherent, pseudomorphic interface at the top surface of the Si bottom p-n junction. We will be able to solve two key materials science issues together ? (i) provide nucleation for III-P semiconductors that normally do not interface well directly with Si atoms and (ii) provide a clean interfacial layer that can electrically passivate the n-type Si emitter layer of the Si bottom p-n junction.

Broader Impact
The National Academy of Engineering selected the top 14 engineering challenges for the 21st century facing humanity worldwide. Challenge #1 - "Make Solar Energy Economical? by ?overcoming the barriers to widespread solar power generation." Our project provides a way to address this societal grand challenge by demonstrating a two stage metamorphic buffer designed to monolithically integrate In0.50Ga0.50P and Si, despite lattice mismatch, into an efficient, affordable and nontoxic solar cell. Two graduate students will be engaged in semiconductor material characterization and epitaxial thin film synthesis. In addition, we will select a K-12 teacher from a local Independent School District to participate in a 6-week summer program. This program will focus on engaging the teacher with our research and the subsequent development of classroom materials for teaching future scientists, engineers, and technologists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to better understand how to improve monolithic integration of different material types on silicon for solar cells, this project investigated and demonstrated an innovative quantum-dot growth approach that focused on optimizing a new lattice strain management concept to control defect formation in epitaxially grown quantum-dot regions. 

 

In addition, the results of the project helped open up unexplored possibilities for advancing other optoelectronic applications such as quantum computation where the current technology has experienced significant limitations and lack of practicable demonstrations of feasibility.  Currently, these types of novel applications remain intractable because constraints connected with strain management and defect control in epitaxially formed quantum dots has not been completely resolved either scientifically or technologically.

 

Finally, the project actively encouraged young women to enter STEM fields by supporting and participating in Girlgeneering summer science and engineering camps on the university campus.  In particular, the PI along with participating graduate and undergraduate students guided the summer camp students in forming “Design Squads” to build motorless devices using shape memory alloys such as flapping artificial butterfly wings. (See Images I and II)  Follow-up surveys show that engaging girls in these summer camp programs has a very positive impact in helping these young women decide on pursuing STEM careers.
